div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7229] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, JULY 3, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.

body.div:
SOCIALISM IN GERMANY. A FRENCH “UNDESIRABLE.’ Berlin, July 6. The Government has forbidden the French Socialist Deputy M. Jaurès to lecture in Berlin upon the international duties of Socialists with reference to war, on the 9th inst., on the ground that the German Social Democrats would utilise the occasion to advance their anti- national efforts. (Reuter.)
Paris, July 6. Prince Radolin has informed M. Rouvier that Germany declines to have M. Jaurès at the Berlin Conference. (Havas.)
FOUNDERING OF FRENCH SUBMARINE. LOCAL AND GENERAL, The Plaque.—Yesterday’s bulletin records two cases, one of which was fatal, at Alex- andria. \ l ./ A Cabinet Council.will be held to-morrow at San Stefano under the presidency of H. E. Fakhry Pasha, Acting Regent. Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Mousky district of Cairo during to-morrow night and at daylight on Sunday, will be poisoned by the police. Ras el-Bar.—A temporary post office for all branches of the service, specie-packets exempt- ed, has been opened at Ras el-Bar, near Da- mietta, for the bathing season. - Bizerta, July 6. A French submarine with 13 on board has * foundered in the lake here. (Reuterjf Ferryville, July 6. The submarine “Farfadet” has sunk with 13 hands. Attempts at rescue are being made. (Eavai.) UNITED STATES. MR. HAY’S SUCCESSOR. Mr. Root, formerly ceeds Mr. Hay. Washington, July 6. Secretary of War, suo- ( Reuter.) GORDON-BENNETT RACE. CUP TO BE RETURNED TO D()NOR. Paris, July 6. The cup will be returned to Mr. Gordon- Bennett, owing to the decision of the 28th June of the Automobile Club of Franoe to no longer take part in the contests. England is the only country besides France, whose three competitors completed the course. (Reuter.) I" — HENLEY REGATTA. Double Execution at Alexandria. —El Sayed Ali Selim and Ramadan Mnrsi, who murdered a female egg-seller at Souk El Bqrsim, will ha executed at Hadra prison on Monday, 10th inst. Suez Canal.—8 vessels passed through the Canal on t’ne 4th inst., of which 3 were British, 2 German, 1 Ottoman, 1 French, 1 Dutch. The day’s receipts were fra! *226,420.69, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,267,505.15. ' Plague Precautions.—The medical officer in charge of the Labbane quarter has ordered a cordon to be drawn round two houses where deaths have occurred which are believed to be directly due to bubonic plague. Henley, July 6. Grand Challenge Cup. The Leander beat the Sport Nautique of Ghent by 2| lengths. Diamond Sculls. Kelley beat Blaokstaffe easily. Time 8 minutes and 10 seconds, which is a record. (Reuter.) RACING. London, July 6. The Princess of Wales Stakes. 1, St. Denis ; 2, Exchequer ; 3, Lancashire. (Reuter.) Egyptian Army.—El Kaimakam Herbert Bey, Assistant Adjutant General, Recruiting Department, will take over command of the Cairo Distriot from El Miralai Matchett Bey, who proceeded to Khartoum on temporary duty yesterday. NAT1VH PRESS OPINIONS. Hashish Smuggling. — A Greek subject, named Nicolas Assimacopoqlos, was arrested this morning while attempting to smuggle four torbas of hashish, which were wrapped round his legs, through the gates, of the Cus- tom-house. ‘Quis Custodies Ipsos Custodes V—The se- cret police arrested Constable Alexandrello, of the City Police, at 6 a.m. to-day on disembark- ing from the S.S. “Athens.” This man was implicated in the recent shooting affray in Sisters-street. Dramatic Performance. »- The Ernesto Rossi dramatic club will give a performance at the Pyramids Theatre on the 12th inst. of an Italian version of Bisson’s comedy Les an LORD CROMER’S SPEECH. In discussing Lord Cromer’s speech, “A1 Moayad” remarks that tho better the reiar tions between Abdeen and Buckingham Palace, the better for Egypt, and that the attitude of the extremists, whose idea of patriotism is a systematic opposition to all that has to do with theV Iccupation, is brainless and even opposed to the principles of the Koran. With Lord Cromer’s four conditions the “Moayad” expresses its agreement subject to one or two reservations. While admitting that a di- rect control of Egyptian afiairs by Parliament would injure Egypt, it remarks that Parlia- ment must never lose its control of what are, after all, its agents in Egypt,and must be able to check any abuse of , their powers. In this connection., it is earnestly to be desired that some means existed of bringing the Egyptian point of view before Parliament as clearly as Lord Cromer’s point of view is set forth in the Blue-books. The caution in the introduction of Western ideas must not be exaggerated, for Egypt has made great strides, and finally, while there is no question of Lord Cromer’s sincere devotion to the good of Egypt, many of his projects have been diverted from their end by those charged to carry them out. "A1 Lewa” expresses its disagreement with “A1 Moayad’s” views. Opposition to the British Occupation is an absolute necessity, and it is strange that “A1 Moayad,"‘after 14 years in opposition, should abandon its policy and support Lord Cromer’s views. The opponents of the Occupation are the only veritable patri- ots. If Lord Cromer’s wishes for the welfare of the Egyptian people are sincere, he should permit them to occupy many of the important positions now reserved for Englishmen, and reduce the expenses caused by the Occupation. , The Egyptians were the first civilised race in the history of the world and are to-day as capable of assimilating modern civilisation as the Japanese or the English themselves. The future will show their capaoity beyond dispute. mm hotel muni ALBX&KDBIA. •a. PCIt BAY, WINE INCLUDED' fSSS9 if 1 Surprises du Divorce. The caste is a strong one and the performance should meet with thh usual success. TUmt.eh Railway Crossings.—It appears that automobiles and carriagSto are frequently driven at great speed over tblf level crossings' on the Ramleh Railway, especially at Bulkeley, which renders the precautions taken by the company valueless, notwithstanding the special watchmen placed on duty at these crossings. The dangers to which antomobilists and car- riage drivers expose themselves are most serious, as with this exaggerated speed it is certain that more often than not the watch- men have hardly time to signal to them before they are on the line. Consequently, we are asked by the company to appeal to the public, when driving over these crossings, to slacken speed in order to avoid any chance of accident. PERSONAL AND SOCIAL Dr. Rucker-Jenisch, German Agent, will leave Cairo for San Sunday. Diplomatic Stefano on Judge Bond, vice-president of the Native Court of Appeal, has left for Zurich. ARISTON AERATED WATERS Guaranteed BlatlUed. ALEXANDRIA: I 7. W «e fa Porta I "gf SfflKSj Mr. II. Boyle, Oriental Secretary to Lord Cromer, left yesterday by the Rubattino boat for Europe. Count von Wedel, First Secretary at the German Diplomatic Agency, is expected back in Cairo on Monday or Tuesday next Abdallah Bev Sfqr leayes for Italy to-day. At Rome he will meet the Maronite Patriaroh, whose visit to Europe has given rise to a variety of conjectures. Major B. W. Longhurst, R.A.M.C., has been granted an extension/ of leave from July 14 to January!8,1906. M. Skinder has been appointed architect to the Aptian hand and Qtfieral Troit sV R A8-EL-B A.R. t/
^ SYRIAN PROTESTANT COLLEGE. , ' 36th ANNUAL COMMENCEMENT EXERCISES. ( From a Correspondent. ) i Beyrout, July 2.- ( For over three decades the Syrian Protestant 1 College stood, as it were, on an eminence as a 1 jeaoonW knowledge shedding a growing light < on Syria, and in its - later phases of develop- ‘ ment it has" plainly become odo of the rnhst - potent educational factors in the Near East. 1 One has but to glance at the latest edition of , ’ its prospectuses, of Which a judicious distribu- 1 tion is annual'y made, to realise the magnitude 1 of its infiuen o and the soope of its field of action. This magnifioent institution reornits < its army,of about • 700 students from various 1 countries. Its radios of power extends from < Armenia in the East to Greeoe and the Etonian 1 sles in the West, and from Asi/Minor in -the • North down to Egypt in the South. But its ] influence has been mostly felt in Egypt, di- < reotly through the preponderant numbhr <Sf < seekers for knowledge that the Land of1 the Pharaohs has always supplied, and indireotly ’ but uo less mightily through the Syrian * settlers who constitute a strong ' intellectual 1 element in Egyptian life, and who, under the 1 strong, capable, and judicious guidance of 1 British rulers, are contributing largely to the 1 progress of the country. Therefore any event 1 of public character in this birthplace of learn- 1 ing should not fail to appeal to the interest of 1 the readers of the “Gazette.” The commencement exercises this year 1 began on Saturday, 24th June, ten days earlier than the usual and traditional time. This has been determined by the early arrival of the mperial Medical Commission from Constan- 1 tinople. Although the exercises commenced on Saturday yet they may be considered to have been publicly inaugurated by the Bhccalaureate service on Snnday, when President Howard Bliss delivered his annual valedictory and exhortatory address to the medical and phar- maceutical graduates: The scene was, as it may easily be imagined, one calonlated to oall Forth deep and stirring emotions and inspire thoughts of the noblest kind, and the young ; ^resident’s fiery eloquence rose splendidly to the occasion. The meeting was well attended by 8tndent8 and many of the public. The bless- ing was fitly given by the old President Eme- ritus, whose appearance in pnblio functions at the college is still inspiring and reoalls to the ieart» of older students happy memories of the godd old dayB. The exercises closed on Wednesday with the ceremony of the distribution of prizes and diplomas. The. principal afid striking •'feature of that day wks the processional march. At Ada Dodge Hall the procession, consisting of the old graduates, the faculty, and the staff of teachers, formed, and proceeded to the Memorial Hall at 3.30 p m. preceded by the American Consol and the Imperial Medical Commission. The President and members of the Faculty wore their'academic gowns, and as it marched forth with measured step and took .ite'Seats on the platform in the Memorial Hall, the procession presented a sight of unusual solemnity. The closing event was a delightful entertain- ment on Wednesday evening at the President’s, Marquand House, wound up by a series of hilarious and comic songs, lustily sung by a part of the American staff of teachers. The entertainment is given principally in honor of the Imperial Medical Commission, composed this year of General Mahmoud Hakki Pasha, a vejy distinguished officer, Colonel Ahmed -p'ehmi Bey, and Major Esoret Roushen Bey. The reception was held in the president's class-room, a hall of specious dimensions, but which, owing to the large crowd, could afford only standing room. This, coupled with the torrid heat of June, made it particularly uncomfortable to the invites, and called forth suggestions from some of them for an enlarge- ment of the hall, which would not be inad- visable considering the growing importance of the'college. But the welcome was so hearty, and there was such a general air of conviviality, that the heat and other little* discomforts were forgotten. Besides, to those blessed with a sense of humour and that rare power of self- detachment, there was afforded a rich fund of/amusement by the presentation of the myites to the Imperial Commission. This 3Anguished body was victimised by a pre- tation of almost all the large crowd of Quests, and for about half an honr there was something like a pantomimic show of a fi'e of ladies and gedtlemen coming forward with different degrees of grace and awkwardness to -hake hands with^ the three commissioners, who cut carious figures, repeating with automatic sameness the stiff, jerky, and deep German how in reply to each introduction. After the ordeal they withdrew to the cooler reoesses of the garden on whioh the hall opens, to indulge in timely refreshments and the necessary accompaniment of the fragrant weed. These entertainments form a cheerful ending for fhe graduates of a year of hard study, wakeful anxieties, and stirring emo- tions, and no donbt they-procure the hospi- table President and his charming wife many a farewell word of blessing from the grateful pupils who are to face the hard realities of life. I had almost forgotten to add that 28 medi- cal students were presented to the Commis- sion for the final examination. Of these one did not oomplete his examination, one failed to pass, 36 took the oath of office before the commission and reoeived their oollege diplomas. Their Turkish diplomas will be sent to them later. Nine pharmacy students were presented to the commissioners lor final examination. 0:' 1 these All pasted pnd took the oath And reo*v- M diplomas. THE EGYPTIAN MARGATE. NOmFW>MuPQ!W.»AID-,
(From a Correspondent.) Now that the summer has began in earnest, many dwellers in inland towns will be thinking of making a move soon to' some favored spot by the seaside where the invigorating ocean : breezes will once more brace the jaded residents of the interior. For those who have the means San Stefano is incomparably the Queen of Egyptian summer resorts,but-to those to whom money is a primary consideration, and others who prefer a free-and-easy and happy-go-lucky existence, I know of no Better place close at hand than Ras-el-Bar, not far from bamietta. I very tfmch doubt whether the frequenters of this little place, which springs into life with the advent of the great heat, would seek to qualify its attractions by comparison with those offered elsewhere, say at Ramleh o/ Port Said, but I do not hesitate to say that it possesses a charm of its own, and I am not surprised when I discern the same familiar faces there^ear after year. * * The season proper at this Egyptian Margate, if I may term it so, does- not commence in earnest until the middle of July, and is in fall swing until about the end of September, So that the hotel-keepers and others who minister to the wants of the strangers have, in a sense, to make My while the sun shines, although, con- sidering the shortness of the season, no one can say that the prices charged are exor- bitant The majority of the visitors are Levantines and Egyptians, leavened by a fair number of Europeans of all the nationalities that inhabit this country. The hotels, if one oan honor them with this name, and dwellings aria mainly if not entirely coDstrncted of the nafive rush mat fastened to wooden uprights and are slighly raised from the land or ground in the same manner as bungalows in India. Naturally, in a country like Egypt, where rain is unknown for nine months at least of the year, snch habitations are possible, but one could not calmly con- template what would happen to the wkole place were it visited by a good monsoon (rain of an hoar’s duration. \ Of course, of amusements of the fashionable kind there are none to begnile the time, bnt for those who love sea-bathing, fishing, and an bnt-of-door life, Ras-el-Bar is a small paradise. The bathing is the best in Egypt, and eaoh hotel has a hnt wherein batherr-oan undress and dress. There are a few shops, sutoh as the -inevitable bacals, & good barber, q chemist, and last, but not least, a branch ppst-office. There is also from Jane, to October ) a small body of police under the \orders of a native officer. » I should not omit to mention, for the infor- mation of would-be new-comers, who may likq to give the place a trial, that there ia a regular steam boat service that. carries the mail between Damietta and Ras-el-Bar, the trip occupying about an hoar and rnnning in ooin- cidence with the arrival of the passenger trains from Mansonrah. Daring the busy season the Egyptian Railway Adminstration runs an ex- press train weekly each way whioh starts from Gairh every Thursday. THE CAIRO HOTELS. THflSPRMBRGED DREDGER, (From our Correspondent). Port Said, Thursday. Work on the submerged dredger “Pharaon. " ill.” is now being rabidly pushed towards com- pletion. I learn that the vessel is to be raised gl by quite a novel method,’ which' should prove “ most interesting. As I noted'some time back, 6< she lies bn her side, And a kind of bed is being r! .dredged ont along her side, at the bottom'of 1 i whioh is to be placed a patent slip cradle. A* g 'cutting is to be made in the bank into which the dredger lying on the cradle is to be towed. ** The entranoe to the basin will be dosed, and it 8 is then to be pumped out and the vessel attend- * ed to as if she lay in a dry-dock. Hopes Are * expressed that the “Pharaon II.” will be hauled into the basjn in two weeks’ time. Np,TES FROM CYjP^IJ^. * • . V DESTRUCTIVE RAIN STORM, (From our Correspondent.) f CHARITY CONCERT. The massed bands of H.M.S. “Suffolk" aod “Lancaster,” by permission of the oaptains and officers of the vessels, are giving a concert on Saturday evening in aid of the Society for tM Prevention of Cruelty to Animals! !Tha concert is to be held in the garden qf the ’ Sastem Exohauge, whioh is being very prettily arranged. ;ly vejy gs* Fehi In reference to the recent rise in the shares of the two leading hotel companies of Egypt, it is worth noticing that the principal reason of the rapid appreciation within the past few months of this class of securities is the enormous increase since two years or so in the value of the land on which the Grand Continental and the Savoy Hotels are built in the case of the Nungovioh Hotels Company, and in the case of the Egyptian Hotels Com- pany, of the land at Ghezireh, whioh has been and is being sold at rapidly increasing prices. The former company bought $he New Hotel, now the Grand Continental, About six years ago, including the land it stands on and the furniture it contained, for £105,000, which, at the time, was considered the foil value. The present-valne of the land alone, whioh measures 11,000 square metres, at the modest price of £20 per square metre, represents an increase of no less than £4 per share on the entire share capital of the company, not reckoning the building, furniture and good-will of a concern that pays yearly dividends of ten per cent The Savoy Hotel,' as it is, was bought about a year later than the other from Prince JDjemil Pasha Toussonm,we believe for£55,000. The land is 5,000 sqoare metres in extent, bnt owing to the' extraordinary increase in the price of land in the best part of the Ismailia quarter the site alone to-day is worth the fifty five thousand pounds, without counting the palatial buildings erected on it. Thiff repre-_ sents an increase in value of at least £2 per share on the whole of the share capital. With these figures before us can one wonder that the £4 shares of the Nungovioh Hotels are now worth £10 or thereabouts, and those of the Egyptian Hotels at an equally1 high premium ? . As we mentioned a few weeks back, the former company hays purchased by pre- emption a portion of the estate of the late Sabet Pasha, adjoining the Savoy Hotel, am on the ground so acquired they are to ereot additional buildings to accommodate the large and ever-increasing clientele that patronises this hotel daring the winter season, besides enlarging the restaurant and making other mnoh-needed, improvements. . -----------P---------------------------------- BECK & CO’jj’fiSEHER BEEB TJ8AB8 HO HOHNfT CONFITITIOH fOR QUALITY. H.8.—Intaiot Brands now Mag otfmg to Man •go* of Mttoin good sotata. Beware ofovOy m*emi nnb* lotoalUe fctty BnmA#* mJm .#£» $ t* THE FOURTH OF JULY MANSOGRAH. AT (From a Correspondent). Mansonrah, July 5. Mr. W. L. Lawton, of the Jewell Export filter Co., having jnst completed the installa- tion of a plant ’ of these filters at the perir waterworks in this town, entertained his numerous friends on the dahabieh “Ariadne,” rindly lent for the occasion by Mr. Dale, yes- terday. Anchored in mid-stream, the rigfeisg dresiled with the flags of all ti&tions, fhatfof the star-spangled banner predominating, with a tapestried awning overhead, and palm- jranches arched over the columns around the sideSj flte dahabieh made a gay show by day. At night, the numberless ooloured lights, strung on high amongst the rigging and al quite tt fairy-hid appearance. On the aland in mid-stream two cannon had been plaoed, the thunders of whioh were interrupted 'by the authorities, it being against the Government regnlAnhqs to fire artillery within 250 metres of th0 town, hut our courteous Moudir ' kindly permitted the fireworks, rockets, Roman candles, etc., on this special oocasion, the first time, in the annals of Mansonrah, that this American fete Ms been oelebrated in such a publio manner. Unfortunately the members of the American Mission were absent, having been > called away- the . previous day to attend a meeting at Alexandria, so that Mr. Lawton was the only citizen present, bnt he a host in hiniself, and received his guests for afternoon tea at 5 o’clock on the deck of the dahabieh. This funotntp over the company crossed over to the island amid- stream, where the gentlemen entertained the ladies by engaging in athletic sports. On their return to the boat, they found a sump- tuous dinner spread out on a table whioh had been prettily decorated with flowers and plants by Mrs. Dale. Toasts, songs, and musio follow- ed to a late hour of the night. Mr. Lawton was ably assisted in the efforts to celebrate his national fete-day by Messrs. McCrae, Anderson, and Holeman, whose hearty bo-operation went far to make the affair the success that it was. Daring the evening, maoh was said in praise of our most energetic Moudir, MustapM Pas hi Saber, for the many improvements he has introduped into the town, amongst them the paving of the main streets, their present oleanlkess and order, and the construotion of a/ carriage drive and promenade Along the hanks of the river, south of the town into the open oonntry. This drive is to be planted with trees, which will form a shady avenue* A new street haj already been commenced, crossing the town and opening up a route from the river to th< open fields by the cemeteries. Not only hat the Mondir had “Benr Adam” at heart in hii endeavours to benefit the town, bnt his esta blishment of a branoh of the Society for th< Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has been s( successful, with the aotive and able support oi hisofficers, the police, and our veterinary snr geon Dr. Trydel, that it is an exception now-a days to find a siok animal about the streets, anc whereas the S.P.C.A’s hospital was Jormerlj crowded with siok blasts, many having to b< shot, all the stalls are now often empty. Nieosu, June 80. f?.'.: '• '»lfr Xt t* • As mentioned, in my last week’s notes, a good deal pfinpenvei^eLee was threatened (o travellers on the Niopei*:Tjopd<» •r91^ ¥* «»-' sequence of $e. damage caused by the heavy rain stonn in the the mountain, stream, whjph( had f bftoofape greatly swollen, washed,/aw^l a portion, of the road which, winds in andLjpntj a^ tknt. point, and, many tons of sited. The Publio Works Department, cam. promptly, to the rescue^ and gangs of men agd ,women wine, v»ry qfodffe^tL, to w«)f to repair, the damage. Little delay qr incon- venience was caused to the officials who were then on their way to their Troodpe enoamp- mpnts, and .the road was openW to traffic after an interval of some 24 hours or so. NEW RAILWAY UNE. a- . - ■ The railway is now laid to within four mile* of Nicosia, and the whole line, frees Nicosia to Famagusta is expected to be completed by about the 1st August. I hear that* the Government is already using the completed portion for the movement o£ grain frees the threshing floors to the gmia atone, which Mve beta established at one or two points along the line. SALE OF GRAIN. The Government has advertised for aalg the following grain of this year's harvest, which represents tithe and recoveries from the seed corn advances : Wheat 316|6QO kilos (English bushels) Barley 411,000 „ Vetches 42j«50. „ „ „ Oats 50,600 „ „ „ all of whioh quantities, with the exception of vetches,-whieh are very (^htiy !h,(ixteto, are less than' those advertised for sale last year. I understand that practically the whole of this has been sold, and at higher prices than in 1904. INVESTIGATION OF FLORA. expert Mr. Jens Holmboe, a Norwegian expert botanist, is now in. Cyprus for the purpose of investigating the flora or the Island on behalf of the Botanical University tiwria- tiania. He Me already spent Borne months in Cyprus and contemplates remaining some THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL. The lengthy text of the judgment of the Court of. Appeal in the Rifahi case has been given to thi Press. It leaves no manner of doubt as to the gailt of the acoused, while it, admits the presenoe of extenuating oiroom- stanoes. < We hear tMt Hassan Bey Wassif has been sent to the infirmary at Menshieh prison owing to a slight indisposition. STRAMBR MOVEMENTS. The S.S/Versiau Prinoe,” from Antwerp, left London yesterday with general osrgo for Malta and Alexandria. The SB. "Tuscan Prinoe,” from Manchester, left Maka yesterday and is dee here on Monday morning next* with passengers and general °*The Khedivial Mail SB. "Isnualia” wilj leave Alexandria on Wednesday for PirsuA Smyrna, Mitylsns and Constantinople. FOOD AND DRUGS ACT. The Food and Drags Act passed lata session by the Legislative Council provides, «n«wig Other things, tMt any purchaser of any ar* tide of food or of a drag or medfeine shaH be entitled; on payment te an' analyst of the sum of five shillfrkgB, to Mve such article or drag or medrane analysed by him, and to receive from thy analyst a oertific&te of the result of his analysis. It Also defines what is fr> be regarded as adulteration uuderthe Act, and hewVffenoes are pnfishaMe. Duly authorised persons are empoiwsBlI to ponltota any suoh articles .**The sapnss purpose of analysis, and power ia givea to thaGont to destroy the sntgeot mattes of. any ejbaqpA It is hoped that the enforoemtat of this law itttf Mve a salutary effect. ■ t C * ■ ta ? * - JEWISH COLONISATION; • A small ohiftlik near Luntoa has lately been acquired by the Jewish Colonisation Society, and it is intended in course of "time to imjtort a limited number of Jewuft people as settlers, who Will be taught to oarry on certain agricultural and industrial under- takings '.here. It is toe soon to praffiothow 'this will answer, hut, if wisely’yianaged anj a capable, industrious, and intelligent oolony is formed, with a Mr amoqnjb ’ tjlf papi^al at, its disposal, it may not be nmyajonaMl to anticipate good results both to the oblohyyAnd, as an object lesson and a meaiU of Intend- ing the trade of the'Island, to Cyprus' ih general.
